div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

argument.p: Messrs, bright and Scholefield on neutral Flags and the Democracy in General — the cotton supply — the Archbishop of Dublin to Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe--a Sympathetic Demonstration to United States Minister Adams.

div4.p: The steamship Australasian brings the latest English dates — from Liverpool on the 18th ult.:
Messrs. Bright and Scholefield, members of Parliament for Birmingham, had again been addressing their constituents on the occasion of the annual banquet of the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce.

Mr. Scholefield in the course of his remarks said, with regard to rights of neutral ships in time of war, he hoped a time would come when nations would no longer contend together in warfare; but while war was the only method of settling disputes, commercial men might mitigate the horrors of war and do something to prevent warfare by urging on the Government moderation and conciliation.
The freedom of commerce and its consequent extension would do much to do away with war. Looking to America, the most gigantic confiscation that ever took place had just been proclaimed by President Lincoln as a military necessity; and he urged generally against conclusions of Mr. Cobden on the subject of international maritime laws.

Mr. Bright said he did not think that success would attend any attemp in Parliament to undo what was done at the Congress of Paris in 1854.
It did not stop at a sensible point; but when it was altered we should go forward, not backward.
The ships of belligerent Powers should be made as safe as the goods of belligerent Powers now are if conveyed in neutral vessels.
Blockading was a less horrible mode of warfare than cannonading, because it did not result in so much loss of life.
It was useless to contend that the more horrible warfare was made the sooner people would require to put an end to it. It did not follow that because war disturbed the commercial element commercial men desired peace.

The result of an armistice in America to-morrow would be ruin to many men in Liverpool who considered themselves rolling in wealth. Blockades were virtually at an end. England could no longer blockade Russia, Prussia, France, Italy, Spain, or Austria.
Railways had stopped that.
If they were to blockade the Northern States of America the price of wheat would be raised from 40s. to 100s. per quarter.
He believed that the interests of all nations, and especially of England, required that we should go forward and not backward in any changes of international law, making it more humane and more consistent with the moral code.
Only England opposed the necessary changes.
If war were made less savage, if peace were made more possible by these changes, men would begin to look to some new mode of settlement other than war. He instanced the Trent affair, in which he declared that no insult was offered to England, and the Government knew that no insult was offered to England, but was not honest enough to let the people know it. Consequently a savage feeling was aroused.
Ten thousand men were sent to Canada in the depth of winter to coerce and menace a nation which could put a million of people in arms.
(Disapprobation.) If we could cultivate a better temper in the people we could arrive at a settlement of quarrels equally just, much more speedy, and less costly in treasure and in life.

After giving his approval to the cession of the Jonian Islands, and urging a like stop in the case of Gibraltar, Mr. Bright adverted to the cotton difficulty in Lancashire.
He said the American war had produced a strange paralysis in Lancashire.
One party destroyed cotton, the other prevented its transport to England.
The quantity of American cotton in existence was variously estimated at about two to four millions of bales; but he believed the stock was much below the higher figure.
An armistice would produce a sudden fall in the present high prices, and sudden ruin to many.
This led him to complain that the Foreign Secretary, by declaring his opinion that the South would soon be independent of the North, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, by his speech at Newcastle, had done great damage to the trading interests in Lancashire, because their remarks were acted upon as though they were eased upon authority and special knowledge, whereas they were as ignorant on the subject as ordinary individuals.

He also charged the London Times with having, partly through ignorance and partly through malice, written such monstrosities about America as to cause most disastrous effects in Lancashire.
Where weight was attached to its utterance the results of its false prophesying had been that people were afraid to do business in Lancashire, and the price of cotton yarn and cloth had never risen in proportion to the rise in the raw material.
With 400,000 bales now in Liverpool, there was only a slight increase in the working of the mills, because of the uncertainty whether prices could be sustained.
Mr. Bright concluded with a peroration rejoicing that in spite of all drawbacks the world was moving in the right direction, and he instanced the emancipation of the slaves in America as one of the evidences.

Mr. Laing, in a letter to the London Times on the cotton supply, says: "Lancashire may be kept on half rations, and saved from absolute starvation during the next two years, by Indian cotton; but effectual and speedy relief can only come from America.
I am convinced, also, that it is for the interest of India that the war in America should soon terminate, so that it may be seen to what normal price cotton will permanently settle down."

A circular had been issued in Liverpool, signed by several very influential men, calling a meeting to test public opinion in that town on the war in America and the emancipation of the negroes.
A preliminary meeting of the promoters was to be held on the Saturday that the Australasian sailed.
A letter is published from Archbishop Whateley, of Dublin, to Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe, in regard to the slavery question and British sentiment in general upon America.--The Archbishop says:

q.p:
Of course there is a great variety of opinion, as may be expected in a country like ours.
Some few sympathize with the Northerners and some with the Southerners, but far this greater portion sympathize with neither completely, but laments that each party should be making so much greater an expenditure of life and property than can be compensated for by any advantage they can dream of obtaining.
He then explains the various views entertained and the causes which have operated against manifestations of sympathy for the North, and concludes as follows: I have now laid before you the views which I conceive to be most prevalent amongst us, and for which I am not myself responsible.
For the safe and effectual emancipation of slaves, I myself consider there is no plan so good as the gradual one which was long ago suggested by Bishop Hinds.
What he recommended was an ad valorem tax upon slaves, the value to be fixed by the owner, with an option to Government to purchase at that price.
Thus the slaves would be a burden to the master, and those the most so who should be the most intelligent and steady, and therefore the base qualified for freedom; and it would be his interest to train his slaves to be free laborers and to emancipate them one by one, and as speedily as he could with safety.
I fear, however, that the time is gone by for trying this experiment in America.

div4.p:
On the 16th ult. a deputation from the Executive Committee of the Emancipation Society waited on U. S. Minister Adams, to present him with their resolutions approving Lincoln's proclamation.
Several of the deputation addressed the Yankee Minister.
Mr. Taylor, M. P., took occasion to say that slavery was the only thing that had caused dissention between England and America.
The Rev. Baptist Noe thought that in a short time the "stain of slavery" would be removed from the country.
Among the members of the deputation was Benj. Scott, Chamberlain of London.
Minister Adams, after acknowledging that he had several times felt hurt by the favor shown to slavery in the London papers, said:

q.p:
I am extremely gratified in the assurances which have been given by several gentlemen with respect to the state of popular feeling in England on this subject.
I have myself had occasion to notice the fact that, although some of the exponents of the public sentiment have appeared to be at times exceedingly harsh upon the United States, yet that when opportunity offered for an appeal to the people themselves the sentiment has uniformly responded to the policy which the U.S. Government have enunciated.
I am, therefore, encouraged to hope that the clouds which have hitherto gathered, and at times somewhat portentously, over the amicable relations of the two countries, have now more and more the appearance of vanquishing from the sky. I feel sanguine that the expression of sympathy from here, which I have been lately the medium of repeatedly communicating to my countrymen, will have the effect of clearing away many impressions that may have been received by reading the attacks of hostile journals, and taking them too much as the true expression of the sentiment of the people.
I think, by understanding distinctly — which they will now have the opportunity of doing — that the policy of Great Britain is not retrograde on the subject of slavery, wherever it may yet exist, and that it is true to the former pledges it so nobly gave to the world of its devotion to the principle of human freedom — the growing conviction of that act will have the effect in America of restoring those amicable relations and reviving those warm sentiments, which ought to be entertained between the two kindred people at all times.
Gentlemen, I shall not longer detain you. I will just say that I shall have pleasure in communicating to my Government a knowledge of the sentiments which have been expressed to-day.

div4.p: The deputation then it is Excellency for the courtesy with which he had received them, and then withdrew.

div4.head: Running the Blockade from Mexico — immense amount of goods sent into Texas--cotton Exported Therefrom.
div4.p:
A correspondent of the New York Herald, writing from New Orleans, says private letters received there state that an immense commerce is carried on by the rebels across the Texan border.
This trade is by no means confined to the Mexicans; but hundreds and thousands of speculators from the North and from other countries are reaping a rich harvest of wealth by supplying the rebels with goods contraband of war, and by taking in exchange cotton and money.
The Mexicans are hostile to the Southern Confederacy; but the Mexican Government is powerless to prevent this immense trade, which has already assumed colossal proportions.
One of the letters, written from Monterey, says:

q.p:
Where is Colonel Hamilton?
If in New Orleans, tell him the rebels are buying up everything that can be eaten, or worn, or used, to kill Union men. It is astonishing to see the enormous quantities of goods that go from here into Texas. Millions of dollars worth of cotton is sold here monthly, all of which is sent back to the rebels by their agents here in the shape of powder, lead, coffee, blankets, shoes, rope, sugar, cotton goods of all kinds, and, in fact, everything that can be used by the army.
An order is here now for six hundred thousand rebel blankets, all of which can be had, and with a sufficient amount of money to pay for them.

div4.p:
Agents are on the frontier, and as far in the interior as San Louis Potosi, buying all the wheat and flour that can be had, and are sending it across the Rio Grande daily.
Most of the goods going from here cross the river at Fort Duncan. * * * Until this trade is out off Texas will not feel the blockade, at least the western part.

div4.head: The cotton Excitement in New York.
div4.p: The Herald, of the 2d inst., commenting on the turn speculation has taken among the Wall street operatives, says:

q.p:
They are abandoning fancy stocks for fancy goods, and now nothing is talked of on Change but the price of long cloths and muslins.
To such a point is the fever of speculation in this line carried that one New England house in this city, whose leading partner holds both gubernatorial and military rank, is realizing, by multiplied commissions on the same invoices of goods, more than their actual cost.
The great majority of the persons concerned in these operations being capitalists outside the trade, the purchases which they make are immediately reinvoiced for sale, and thus stocks of goods, worth in the aggregate from five to one hundred thousand dollars or more, are daily changing owners without changing warehouse, securing thereby to the firm selling them an amount of commission exceeding their actual value.
Some idea of the enormous amount of its gains in this way may be gathered from the fact that it sold the other day a single invoice, amounting to $120,000, at prices exceeding by three hundred per cent. those of twelve months ago. Thus these New England manufacturers and commission houses, whose principals have been mainly instrumental in bringing the country into its present ruined condition, have not only realized large fortunes by contracts and the protection of a war tariff, but are continuing to make further enormous gains by the commercial embarrassments which they have provoked.
It is no wonder that whilst such a profitable condition of things lasts they should be anxious to throw every obstacle in the way of a vigorous prosecution of the war. Our present troubles are mainly laid to the account of New England fanaticism.
If they were set down to that of New England cupidity they would be equally near the truth.

div4.head: The report about the Florida — the Dates of her Sailing.
div4.p: In the suspense which will be felt until the fate of the C. S. steamer Florida is certain, the following dates of her movements, from the New York Herald, will be interesting:

The steamship Eagle, which left Havana on the 24th ultimo, reported that the rebel steamer Florida (Oreto) left Havana on Thursday morning, the 22d, having coaled during the night.
She had arrived at that port on the 21st.
She had pushed on towards Matanzas, and had destroyed four vessels between there and Havana.
This account brings the certain news of the arrival of the Florida in the vicinity of Matanzas.

Captain F. A. Small, of the Corris Ann; writes that on the evening of the 22d his vessel was burned by the rebel steamer Florida in the very harbor of Cardenas.
There was no doubt as to the identity of the rebel steamer, and this report shows her position on the night of the 22d.

The captain of a vessel arriving at Havana on the 26th reports a war steamer painted white in full chase of another painted black, and with two smokestacks.
This answers the appearance of the Oreto, or Florida, which fact could hardly have been ascertained by the captain of the reporting vessel.
The rebel vessel was then off the Bahamas.

The Cayuga is reported to have announced the fact that three steamers were seen firing upon another steamer that was on fire.
As the Creole arrived on the morning of the 28th, it must have been on the 26th or 27th that she was informed of the news, and some little interval must have occurred between the time the Cayuga saw the destruction of the vessel and the time she reported the same.

Reviewing all the reports from the various sources it appears more than probable that the chased vessel was the Oreto or Florida; that she was driven westward upon some of the banks in the vicinity or within the hearing of the report of guns, off Cardenas; was there fired upon and perhaps burned by the shells from the Union gunboats or the match of her captain, and has been destroyed.
We await further intelligence.

div4.head: California treasure going to England.
div4.p: The steamship Sonora has sailed from San Francisco for Panama, with one million and a quarter of dollars for England, while for New York she brings but three hundred thousand dollars. The Herald says:

q.p:
We would call the attention of our Navy Department to this fact, which proves that since the capture of the Ariel by the Alabama the treasure of California is sent to England instand of coming here.
Before this occurrence at least seven-eights of the California treasure came to New York; now we get but one-eighth.
All this is, we charge, the fault of our Navy Department, which has ever proved deaf to the entreaties and remonstrances of our mercantile classes, and has failed to protect our commerce.
From all sources the Navy Department heard of the plans of the rebel privateers in time to have defeated them.
Is our commerce to be driven from the ocean in order to keep Mr. Welles in office?
We have no hope while he remains Secretary of the Navy.

div4.head: The discussion on the African-regiment bill.
div4.p:
It was stated yesterday that the African-regiment bill had passed the United States House of Representatives by a vote of 84 to 55.
The debate was prolonged and sometimes bitter.
We give the following extracts:

Mr. Stevens said he was of the opinion that the existing law did not put the African soldier on the same footing with the white soldiers.
Hence if any of the former be captured by the enemy and executed, the Executive would not have authority to punish or retaliate.
The bill under consideration proposed to confer this authority.

Mr. Cox, of Ohio, said he would prefer having the gentleman's opinion to that of the War Department.
The gentleman knew that the law placed colored persons now in the army under the rules and articles of war.-- They receive pay and rations in all respects as part of the army.
Then let it be known where is the necessity of this bill?
Mr. Washburne (Ill.) inquired whether the gentleman did not vote for the existing law?
Mr. Cox (Ohio) replied that he did not, and because the infamous 12th and 13th sections of that bill were not out he and his friends voted against it.

Mr. Stevens said that in form the old enactment did not put the African soldier precisely on the same footing.
If the bill now proposed was a re-enactment of that law, what was the objection?
If it altered a law for the better, then it was necessary.
Mr. Wadsworth (Ky.) rose to speak, when
Mr. Kellegg (Ill) objected to further debate, as the members had set up all last night in order to reach an action to-day.
Mr. Stevens said it was thought better by those who designed the bill that the question of bounty should be left out altogether.
Mr. Mallory (Ky) asked the gentleman whether the President, under this bill, would not have the power to appoint negroes to command white men?

Mr. Wilson (Iowa).--Compare this bill with the existing law, to show that the black are not proposed to be placed on the same footing with white men. Did the gentleman think the President would place black officers over white men?

Mr. Mallory replied that it was impossible for him to say what the President would do. He said the object of his moving to refer was that the bill might be deprived of those features which made it odious without a counter-vailing advantage to the United States. Congress had already provided that the President may employ such persons of African descent as he may deem useful under this bill; not only black Brigadiers, but black Major-Generals, might be appointed.
The opposition of the border State men was not factions.
It was made in seriousness, because it would produce a serious injury.
They had submitted to a good many things which they considered injudicious, but he begged gentlemen that when they found it necessary to adopt measures in violation of their judgment they will make the does as palatable by gilding the pill.

Mr. Dunn (ind.) was favorable to the policy of this bill.
He could see no reason why any man of any color, who is able to lift his arm for the defence of his nationality, should not be permitted to do so. He could see no reason why a black man's life should be spared, and his own son called upon to lay down his life; or why persons who are considered property by those in rebeldom should not be brought in some way into active service, if they will enlist on the side of the Government.
At the same time he was deeply impressed with the ideas thrown out by the gentleman from Tennessee, in his brief remarks.
They must not only consider what is right and proper in itself, but must pay some deference to public sentiment and prejudice.

It was known that there is already in the public mind a deep prejudice against the blacks being placed on a basis of social equality with the whites.
He did not believe the President would ever permit black officers to command white men. He had no idea that the President was so ignorant of the popular feeling as to do so foolish a thing.
Yet, unless some restrictions are thrown around this bill, those who wish to strengthen and additionally disseminate this prejudice, will seize upon every point to accomplish their purpose.

Mr. Mallory said that the bill of Mr. Stevens placed the whites and blacks on a military equality.
If a black officer held a higher commission, did he not necessarily take the precedence of a white officer?
Mr. Dunn replied that it was because he did not wish such a possibility to exist in the public mind, that he wished the bill to provide explicitly that blacks shall not command white men.
Mr. Porter (Ind.) offered an amendment to meet this point.

Mr. McPherson (Pa.) said the author of this bill would confine the officering to white men. [Voices.--Who is the author?
Name him.]
Mr. Wickliffe.--The author is the Secretary of War.

Mr. McPherson further explained that those on whom the responsibility rests of executing the law will confine the provision of officering to white men, reserving the exception that it might be considered just and proper to appoint as officers blacks who might distinguish themselves by military ability, instead of confining them to the ranks.
Mr. Dunn had no idea that any man, or the President, or Secretary of War, would place a black man as an officer over white men, but he did not wish cavillers to raise their clamor against this bill.

Mr. Cox said that by another section of the existing law, the President can employ black men in any way he may see proper, and organize them for the suppression of the rebellion without limitation.
So the President could do just what he pleased — make the blacks Colonels, Brigadiers, or Major-Generals, without further legislation.
Mr. Dunn concluded his remarks in favor of amending the bill by the limitation he suggested.

Mr. Wickliffe spoke against the employment of negroes as soldiers.
A man named Hunter had attempted to organize a regiment of blacks.
Fifty thousand French rifles at eighteen dollars apiece, and ten millions of dollars worth of clothing, were sent to Hilton Head, and what become of the experiment?
Why two hundred of them immediately deserted, taking away their rifles on their shoulders.--He understood that the regiment was disbanded.
The Government had been supporting the runaway negroes, yet the gentleman from Indiana said they had been more profitable than wasteful.
Mr. Dunn replied that that was his information from an officer of the Government.

Mr. Wickliffe said his information was different.
It was declared by the Secretary of War that every pound of cotton raised at Milton Head had cost the Government twenty dollars per pound.
He repeated that the money had been misapplied to feeding and clothing contraband slaves.
The President, under this bill, had a right to designate who shall take command.
As an American citizen, he looked upon it with humiliation.
It was now proposed, for the first time, to put in the form of law, that the negro is socially equal to the white man — placing Captain Sambo and and Captain Joe side by side on a perfect equality.

During the remarks of Mr. Wickliffe, he spoke of the sword recovered by Gen. Butler, and which belonged to the rebel Twiggs, and now proposed to be given to General Butler.
What, apart from the negro question, had Butler done, and in what field had he distinguished himself?
The Speaker reminded the gentlemen that the question of Twiggs' sword was not before the House.

Mr. Wickliffe replied that he wanted to show that the service of the negroes had demoralized Butler.
He did not know a more befitting receptacle for the rebel sword than Butler.
It was a dishonored sword; let it go.
The Speaker again reminded the gentleman that the sword was not before the House.

Mr. Wickliffe--No; but it will be pretty soon, and I will not have a chance to speak.
He said that the negroes when they fired their guns at Hilton Head fell down with the fright.
He made further remarks against the policy of employing black soldiers.

Mr. Lovejoy (Ill.) said that while there was a fierce, unscrupulous, and almost revolutionary organization, known as the Democratic party, in free States, resisting the draft for recruiting the army and preserving the life of the Union, they see another party here opposing every effort to obtain soldiers from another source.
Unscrupulous at the rebels, these sympathizing Democrats say "you shall not have a man." The gentleman from Kentucky, who is for perpetuating the cause for which he pleade, said, last might that he would eat, sleep, and drink here till the 4th of March rather than consent that this bill should pass.--And this is Democracy.
He would give the gentleman credit for being consistent while he was persistent.
At the breaking out of the rebellion it was distinctly manifested to the House that he preferred slavery to Union.--This he showed by his conduct, rather than words.

Mr. Wickliffe said that on a former occasion the gentleman asked him a question under the figure of a ship in a storm; and further, whether he preferred the destruction of slavery to that of the Union?
To which he had responded that he would throw Lovejoy and all the Abolitionists overboard and save the ship.
[Applause and hisses, which the Speaker promptly checked.]
Mr. Lovejoy now asked him whether, if it was necessary to emancipate the slaves in order to save the Union, he would consent that this should be done?

Mr. Wickliffe.--I reply in the Yankee fashion.
Do you prefer the emancipation of the negro to letting the Union slide?

Mr. Lovejoy--That is a meaner way than any Yankee ever put a . I am for the Union first and last, forever, by any and all means.
The gentleman spoke about one Hunter, as if he were a contemptible individual, of whom the nation knew nothing.
General Hunter bore scars received in the battle of freedom.
The gentleman thought it proper to indulge in remarks about the sword which the House voted to Gen. Butler.
The Speaker reminded Mr. Lovejoy that the subject of the sword was not before the House.

Mr. Lovejoy.--It was brought here not by me, but by the gentleman from Kentucky.
I protest not only in the name of justice, but common decency, against what he said.
Mr. Wickliffe.--Will the gentleman yield the floor for a moment?
Mr. Lovejoy.--Not unless you answer my question.
Mr. Wickliffe.--The country knows him and knows me.

Mr. Lovejoy replied: That is a fact.
He said Gen. Butler was a marvellously proper and chivalrous man not long ago, in the estimation of the gentleman and his associates, but had suddenly been transformed from a high minded to an infamous man. It was demoralizing now for him to have command of negroes or "niggers." For himself, he never said "niggers." That was not correct, and, as the Secretary of State says, "no one can be elected President who says nigger." [Laughter.] He wanted to know whether the gentleman from Kentucky would have received the vessel piloted out of Charleston by Robt. Small?
Mr. Wickliffe.--Just as soon as I would receive anything from you.

Mr. Lovejoy.--There is another exemplification of the degradation of slavery.
[Laughter.] Would you return Robert Small as a fugitive?
Mr. Wickliffe--I'll answer no more questions.

Mr. Lovejoy.--That shows more wisdom than I have yet seen manifested by the gentleman.
During his speech he said he would rather follow a black man than a slaveholder.
He feared the latter would betray him; the former would not. He would arm mules, to make them shooting machines, if he could.--He had never seen an animal with ears so long, though it brayed "democracy," which was not good enough to kick out the brains of rebels.
[Laughter,]

Mr. Dunn said he thought that such a general denunciation of the Democratic party would have a bad effect; for he, at least, had confidence in the loyalty of the great mass of the people, no matter to what party they belonged.
Mr. Lovejoy replied that the gentleman's confidence in this respect did not exceed his own.

Mr. Dunn said he was glad the gentleman from Kentucky had indulged in the freedom of debate.
He seemed to be a lingering relic of the dynasty which so long tyrannized over the nation.
The gentleman had charged that he (Mr. Dunn) had abandoned the faith and belief that the white men of the North can crush out the rebellion.
At the time when the rebellion broke out he (Mr. Dunn) was opposed to the employment of negro soldiers.
He then thought there was a loyal sentiment among the whites of the South which would make itself efficient in the way. This was not so. He had made another discovery, namely, that men with black skins had white hearts, and loyal hearts; if they are willing to risk their lives for the cause in which they have so deep an interest, he saw no reason why they should not take part in the fight.

The gentleman from Kentucky spoke about a loyal black Captain being exchanged for a rebel white Captain, a proceeding which the gentleman condemned.
But he (Mr. Dunn) believed that a black man, either private or Captain, who was fighting for his country, was better than a traitor, though through his Anglo-Saxon skin you can count the veins of his face.
The loyal black was not only equal, but superior to the white traitor fighting against his country.
He had a son fighting on the right side, and he would prefer that this son should be saved by true loyal black men, than go to his grave beneath the stroke of a white traitor.

In reply to the remarks of Mr. Wickliffe about Gen. Butler, Mr. Dunn referred to the course of Gen. Jackson in employing black troops at New Orleans, and Com. Perry on Lake Erie.
Also, to the testimony of Commodores Stringham and Woodhull in the present war; the last named saying to him that the negroes had fought with remarkable bravery.
The rebels employ the blacks whenever they can. Why should not we?
Why should they not be educated to conquer traitors?
He did not want the white men to perish in order to keep traitors in subjection while we have a population who can live in the South like alligators, and can perform the duty required.
If the blacks would, as the gentleman from Kentucky seemed to fear, commit acts of savage barbarity, then what had become of the Southern teachings of Christianity?
Mr. Lovejoy concluded his remarks.

Mr. Crittenden (Ky.) said that the instances of the blacks being heretofore employed in warfare were so rare as to be insignificant.
It was an assertion in favor of the present bill about which gentlemen, as in the days of chivalry, might break a lance, but it was no argument becoming them for serious consideration.
Should we be asked to stigmatize our constituents — free white men — by saying that they would shrink from the contest in which they are now engaged, and that blacks should be employed to perform the work of patriotism?

The blacks are not necessary to put down the rebellion, they are not worthy to aspire to the position of freemen; all know the distinction which exists as to social equality.--After peace was restored are arms to be left in the hands of black men in the South?
The Janissaries were safer keepers of the Ottoman empire than would be the freed slaves in this country, and to so employ them was a crime against the age and violation of the Constitution.
If this bill was passed into a law it would be unconstitutional and hence null and void.
Was it proposed to inaugurate a servile war, led on by white men? --With all the faults of those in the South in arms, he loved them still.
He fought against them, not because he hated them; but because they were arrayed against our liberties and form of government.
His principles were permanent and fixed.
He was for the restoration of the Union as it was, and the Constitution as it is.

div3.head:
V. T. Crawford,
Attorney at law,
div3.p: Will practice in the various Confederate and stated Courts in the city of Richmond and will also prosecute claims against the Confederate States, and perpetuate testimony in the case of lost slaves harbored by the enemy.
Office on Bank street, between 11th and 12th. Box No. 732.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--I have for hire for the balance of the year, a No. 1 Cooper.
Farm Hands.
Tobacco Hands, Cooks, Washers, and Ironers, Nurses, and Chambermaids, Dining Room Servants, and House Boys.
For terms apply to
div3.closer:
Wm. S. Phillips,
On 12th st, bet. Main and Bank. fe 6--2t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A Girl 12 or 14 years of age, accustomed to the duties of the house.
To a good home the price will be moderate.
Apply to Joseph H Colquitt, head of Grace street, near old Fair Grounds.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A small negro Boy, accustomed to wait in the house.
Inquire at Davidson & Chock Lay S. Cary st.

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p:
--A fine and very likely yellow Boy, nineteen or twenty years old. He is very capable, a swift, active waiter, and quite a good cook; would make a capital servant for an officer.
Apply at Grady's jail.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A good Cook.
Washer and Ironer.
Apply to

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 33, page 2.

div3.head: Can the Union of these States be restored?
div3.p:
In his late great speech, Mr. Vallandigham says: "Many States and peoples ones separated have become united through the course of ages through natural causes, and without conquest; But I remember a single instance only, in history, of States or people once united and speaking the same language, who have been forced permanently asunder by civil strife or war, unless they were separated by distance or vast natural boundaries.
And who now, North or South, in Europe or America, looking into history, shall say that because of civil war the union of these States is impossible ? War, indeed, while it lasts, is disunion, and, if it lasts long enough, will be final and eternal separation first, and anarchy and despotism afterwards."

The exception to the general rule, which Mr. Vallandigham lays down, is, doubtless, Germany, the people of which speak all the same language, and yet are separated into a score of States.
It is obvious why he selected this case to make an exception of it. It is the strongest in point for those who believe that secession is inevitable, and has often been used as an example.
It could be gotten rid of in no other way than by shoving it aside into a limbo of exceptions, where it might be left to sleep in oblivion.
But it will not thus be passed over. --The case of Germany is strictly analogous to the case of the late United States.
It was originally composed of a number of small principalities each independent of the other, and managing its own internal affairs in its own way, while all acknowledged a sort of allegiance to the Emperor of Germany.
The thirty years war and the peace of Westphalia broke up this arrangement, and separate kingdoms grew up in Germany, who ever since have been negotiating and fighting with each other as independently as France and England might have done.
They are in fact so many distinct nations.
Germany, however, is not the only example.
All Italy speaks the same language, and until three or four years ago it had been separated into a number of States for centuries.
It was all united under the Roman Government.
Let us try a separate existence four or five hundred years, as the Germans and Italiana did.

Mr. Vallandigham makes a great mistake in supposing this to be a civil war. It is not a civil war. It is a sectional war. It is a war between two peoples who are as distinct as the Russians and the Danes, or the Saxons and Dutch.
Nor do we speak the same language.
The language of the South is the English language.
The language of the North is English, Dutch, German, Spanish--a compound, in a word, of every known language and dialect in the world.
The population of the South is homogeneous.
That of the North is more heterogeneous than that of the Austrian Empire.
The great wonder is not that the two sections have fallen asunder at last but that they held together so long.
It would be almost as rational to form the whole continent of Europe into a single State, and then expect it to continue such.

Mr. Vallandigham takes up the old geographical argument on which General Webb used to filiate with so much unction, and which was adopted by Lincoln in his last annual Message.
Nothing can form the boundaries, it seems, of States but great landmarks.
All the communities living on a great river must belong to the same Government.
Certain elevations or natural water sheds control everything in the direction in which the water from them flows.
Any man who knows anything of history and geography knows that this style of argument is perfectly ridiculous.
How many nations are there on the Rhine?
How many on the Danube?
How many on the Po?
Where is the grand natural division between Spain and Portugal?
Between France and Belgium?
Between Bavaria and Austria?
Between Germany and Russia?
As for the water shed argument, it is sufficient to know that Switzerland is the water-shed of all Western Europe.

The lines of demarcation arise from the character of the people.
If they are hostile to each other they do not want waters or mountains to separate them.
If they are not, waters and mountains can not keep them asunder.
The idea that this whole continent is to be occupied by one nation is simply preposterous.
In five thousand years the world has never seen such a thing as 200,000,000 of people speaking the same language and enjoying free institutions, all under the same Government.
It is a dream of Utopian folly to suppose that it ever can exist.
The separation has begun, and it will continue.
America, like the Old World, is to be settled by many nations.
Such is its destiny.

div3.head: Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Five deserters from the Abolition army arrived at the Libby prison yesterday from the Blackwater, the vicinity of the recent engagement between Gen Pryor and Peck's forces.
Their names are John Ramlek, co C 69th N Y; John Roy, co D, do; Chas Benss, co G, do; Victor Alley, co A, 155th N Y; John Forrester, co C, do; Three of them, it will be perceived, belonged to the famous 19th, formerly commanded by the notorious Corcoran.
From Gordonsville and Staunton the following arrived at the same prison: A C Brockway, co A, 6th Ohio cavalry; A Habbard, 1st Md cav, taken at Occaquon creek; T J levans, Sergt Major 1st Va Abolition cav; W P Merrill, Sergt, co A, do; and nine privates of the 3d Va Abolition cav, taken at Elk Mountain, in Pocahontas county.
Also, three members of co G, 2d Va Abolition artillery, taken at the last named place.

div3.head: Execution postponed.
div3.p:
--The execution of Michael Bunton, condemned to be hung yesterday, was postponed, by order of the Governor, to the 27th inst, at the solicitation of a number of citizens, who did not think the condemned had had sufficient time to make preparation for the awful event, all due preparations for which had been made by the City Sergeant.
The execution of James Broderick and Michael Kearns, of the Detcher battery, appointed to take place yesterday, was postponed for ten days by a reprieve of the President of the Confederate States.

div3.head: The State Line prisoners.
div3.p:
--Over one hundred of the Yankees taken by Gen. Floyd are now imprisoned in the upper stories of the Virginia Armory building, on 7th street. Some dozen or more of the most prominent are in the Virginia Penitentiary.
Two of the number, viz: Capt. William Cramm, of Philadelphia, and Lieut. Isaac A. Wade, of Putnem county, have been put at hard labor in retaliation for Lincoln's putting two Confederate officers in the Washington (D C) Penitentiary on the trumped up charge of robbing the mails.

div3.head: Bank Directors appointed.
div3.p:
--The following Directors for the Graziers Bank, at Jeffersonville, Tazewell county, were appointed by the Governor yesterday, viz: Sterling F Watta, Harvey G Perry, Eilas G Harman, and Jas N Thompson.
The Stockholders appointed Messrs Henry F Perry, E S Howard, W O Yost, W P Cacti, and Henry S Sowen, Directors on their part.
The Graziers' Bank was formerly the Bank of Northwestern Virginia, but had its title changed by act of the General Assembly.

div3.head: Sale of Real estate.
div3.p: --The large three story brick building on the west side of 18th, between Grace and Broad streets, owned by Mr. James Kinuaird, was sold yesterday at public vendue, by Messrs. Goddin & Apperson, for $10,000, Mr. Wm. J. Eowen becoming the purchaser.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --A men named Thomas S. Hall was arrested yesterday by officers Crone, Davis, and Chaikley, and caged, to await an examination before the Mayor on the charge of stealing a set of harness from Edw. D. Eacho, worth $150.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p:
Mayor's Court--Feb. 6th.--The case of Wm. B. Warden, for obtaining two hogsheads of sugar by false pretences from Richard Cawthorn, was partly heard and continued till Tuesday.
Miss Jennie Taylor, an actress was arraigned for using abusive language towards Mrs. Constance Vance, another actress; and Henry Vance and L. D. Glenn, were arraigned for threatening to assault said J. Jennie Taylor.
The parties reside in the old Swan Tavern, on Broad street, and the disturbance between them had its origin in a dispute about their respective rights to certain privileges appurtenant to the house.
The evidence at first arising grew into details given in language unfit for ears polite.--The parties were admonished and discharged.--John Robinson, a free man of color, was ordered 15 lashes for stealing seven hens owned by a market man. John Frayer, for assaulting and threatening to shoot James Pendleton, was bound over to keep the peace for twelve months.
A summons against James Robinson, a free man of color, for siding a horse on the side walk of Main street, contrary to the city ordinances, was dismissed.
Supreme Court of Appeals.--The following decisions in cases pending before this Court were announced this week, Judges Allen, Daniel, Moncure, and Robertson, presiding:

Creighton vs. Brashear, &c. argued by R. T. Daniel for the plaintiffs; and Arther A. Morson for the defendants.
Judgment of the Circuit Court of Fauquier county reversed.
Sheppard vs Roper; argued by Andrew Hunter for the plaintiff, and John Handolph Tucker for the defendant.
Judgement of the Circuit Court of Jefferson reversed.

Not in Session.--None of the courts of record, save the Court of Appeals, were in session yesterday.
Judge Lyons's Court concludes its present passion to-day.

div4.p:
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M, Mr. Hunter, of Va., in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Henry A. Wise, of the Episcopal Church.

Mr. Baker, of Florida, introduced a bill to "amend an act entitled an act to alter and amend an act for the sequestration of estates, property, and effects of alien enemies, and for indemnity of citizens of the Confederate States, and persons aiding the same, in the existing war with the United States, approved 15th February, 1862." Referred.
Mr. Phelan, of Miss, submitted joint resolutions proposing an exchange with the several States of the bonds of the Confederate States for the bonds of the said States, which was referred.

Mr. Orr, of S. C., introduced a bill converting the 1st regiment South Carolina infantry into the 2d regiment South Carolina artillery.
Referred.

Mr. Barnwell, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill "to authorize the lane of bonds for funding Treasury notes," which provides that the Secretary of the Treasury shall issue coupon bonds and certificates of stock, interest payable semi-annually, at 8 per cent, interest yearly, for such amount as may be required in exchange for Treasury notes which are now fundable in 8 per cent, bonds, and also to pay for any subscription to the Produce Loan which may remain unpaid after exhausting the one hundred million loan, &c --Seven per cent certificates shall also be issued for all fundable 7 per cent. Treasury notes.
Both shall be made payable at the end of 10 years, or may be extended to 25 years. The bill was read the requisite number of times and passed.

Mr. Barnwell, of S. C., reported back, without amendment, from the Finance Committee, House Deficiency bill.
The bill was passed and sent back to the House.
The bill granting transportation to furloughed soldiers was transferred to the secret calendar.

The bill organizing the Supreme Court came up next in regular order, and the question being a motion to repeal the 45th and 46th sections of the Judicial act of the Provisional Congress. Mr. Johnson addressed the Senate in favor of the amendment.
At the conclusion of his remarks Mr. Wigfall obtained the floor, but on motion of Mr. Johnson of Arkansas, the Senate agreed to take up the bill granting transportation to furloughed soldiers.

Mr. Semmes, of La, moved that when the Senate adjourned to-day it adjourn to 12 o'clock on Monday.
Agreed to.
The Senate then went into secret session, on motion of Mr. Johnson, of Arkansas.
Adjourned on opening the doors.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Speaker.
Resolutions Reported and Referred.--By Mr. Chambins, of Va, a resolution as follows, which was agreed to:

q.p: Whereas, many of the bast, most valuable, and patriotic citizens of the Confederate States, have been driven from their homes by the public enemy, have withstood the seductions, and remained firm and loyal to their attachments to the Southern cause, and have sacrificed their property in consequence of their devotion to their country; and, where as, such loyal citizens are entitled to the respect, the sympathy, and the aid of the Government: Therefore, be it.

div4.p: Resolved, That the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of passing a law relieving from taxation during the war all loyal citizens who have been forced to flee from their homes by reason of the presence of the Northern army.

By Mr. Davidson, of N. C., a resolution requesting the President to inform the House what sum or sums of money have been vested or funded for the Cherokee Indians, east of the Mississippi, out of "the removal and subsistence fund," under the treaty of New Echota, of 1835-36, by the United States, when the same was so funded, when the interest was last paid, what legislation has heretofore been enacted by the United States, and what legislation is now necessary to carry into effect the late treaty stipulations with said tribe.
Bills Introduced--By Mr. Chamblins, of Va: A bill to increase the pay of the clerks at the Naval Station at Charlotte, R. C. Referred to Committee on Naval Affairs.
Reports from Committees--Mr. Chambers, of Miss: From the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back from that Committee a bill heretofore offered by Mr. Vest, of Mo., with a substitute as follows:

q.p: The Congress of the Confederate States do enact:-- That an act entitled "an act in relation to the transfer of troops," approved Sept. 23d, 1862, be and the same is hereby repealed, and that it shall be the duty of the Secretary of War to transfer any private or non-commissioned officer who may be in a company, battalion or regiment, from a State of this Confederacy other than his own, to a regiment from his own State, whenever such private or non-commissioned officer may apply for such transfer, and it shall not be necessary to obtain such transfer to secure the consent of the company; regiment, brigade, division, or corps commander to whose command such private or non-commissioned officer may belong, or to which he may apply to be transferred; but is shall be sufficient to require the applicant to report to the commanding officer of the regiment to which he applies to be transferred, by whom he shall be placed in the company of his choice in that regiment, unless such company shall be already full to its maximum, in which case the said commanding officer may place him in any other company of that regiment: Provided, that this act shall not apply to any one who has enlisted as a substitute.

div4.p: Mr. Read, of Ky., submitted an amendment as follows, which was agreed to:
Sec. 2, That whenever the Secretary of War shall grant a transfer, agreeably to the above provisions, to any soldier in the service, he shall furnish transportation also.
Mr. Ralis submitted an amendment to the first section, which was rejected.

Mr. Dupree, of La., moved that the bill and amendments be postponed and printed.
Lost — ayes 33 noes 34.

The pending question was upon the substitute as amended, when Mr. Hilton, of Fla, offered an additional amendment, as follows: Provided, That this act shall only be extended to persons who enlisted in regiments from other States before the secession of their own States.
This amendment was lost — ayes 29, noes 34.
The substitute of the committee was than adopted in lien of the original bill, and ordered to its engrossment, read a third time and passed.
Mr. Rails, of Ala., moved to reconsider the vote by which the bill was passed, which motion lies over.

Mr. Kenner, of La., from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported back the bill for funding the currency, with an amendment, which was made the special order for Tuesday next, and ordered to be printed.
On motion, the House then went into secret session.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Lieutenant Governor. --Prayer by Rev. Dr. J. C. McCabe.

Mr. Dickinson, of Prince Edward offered a resolution that Major General Sterling Price be invited to a seat on this floor.
Adopted, and a committee appointed to wait on him and announce the fact.

Resolutions of Inquiry--By Mr. Dauglas: To request the Governor to take such steps as are necessary to make the organization of the State Line conform in all respects to the requirements of the act of May 17, 1862. By the same: Into the necessity of continuing the Pay Department of Virginia.
By the same: Of requiring all requisitions for supplies or money for the use of the State Line to be made on the Quartermaster-General of the State, &c. By Mr. Thompson: On allowing the committee of John Haskins to sell the stocks now held by him, and to invest the proceeds thereof in stocks of the Confederacy.
By Mr. Whittle: On amending the Code so as to exclude all foreigners not in the public service from the right of citizenship; and also such citizens of this State as by decisive acts, since the secession of this State, have acknowledged the authority of the United States or of the usurped Government attempted to be established within its limits.
By Mr. Neeson: A resolution of about the same tenor as the foregoing.
An adverse report of the Committee on Lunatic Asylums, as to the expediency of providing for the temporary support of lunatics who cannot be accommodated elsewhere at present, was made.

During the proceedings Major General Price entered the Senate chamber, accompanied by the committee, and was welcomed and invited to a seat on the floor in a neat and eloquent speech by the Lieutenant Governor.
Gen, Price expressed his thanks for the honor, and then received the introduction to the Senators personally.
On motion of Mr. Frazier, the Senate adjourned

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr Reid.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Baskervill: Into the expediency of authorizing County Courts, when required under existing laws to furnish negroes to work upon fortifications, to substitute free negroes instead of slave labor; also, into the expediency of amending and re-enacting an act passed March 14, 1862, extending the time for the exercise of certain rights and privileges, go as to extend the same in cases of criminal prosecutions.

On motion of Mr. Pockridge, the act appropriating pay to Brig.Cen.
Bickley for militia services rendered in the spring of 1861, in performing the duties of Brigade-Inspector over the brigades which he commanded, was taken up.
Mr. Richardson opposed the appropriation.
Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, advocated it.
A motion was made for its indefinite postponement, which provailed.

The Extortion Committee reported back the bill and amendments heretofore before the House, together with substitutes offered by Messrs. Hunter, Anderson of Rockbridge, and Mallory.
A motion to make it the order of the day for to-morrow at 12 o'clock, was lost.

Mr. Forbes submitted a resolution declaring that all debate on the bill, its amendments and substitutes, shall cease at 2 o'clock on Saturday, and that the House will then proceed to vote thereon.
Upon which the ayes and noes were called — the vote stood; Ayes 59, noes $9
On motion, the discussion of the bill, etc., was limited to ten minutes.

The first business before the House was upon the motion of Mr. Anderson to strike out all after the first four sections in the committee's bill, and insert his substitute as a substitute for the whole bill.
Pending its discussion an ineffectual effort was made for a night session, and finally, without coming to a vote, the House adjourned.

div3.p: The reported murder of Rev. A. H. H. Boyd, of Winchester, Va., by the Federals, proven to be unfounded.

div3.head:
Latest from the North.
[from our own Reporter.]
div3.p: --I have received New York papers of the 2d and 3d, and the Philadelphia Inquirer, of (Wednesday,) the 6th inst., and send you the following summary of their contents:

q.p: The special New York correspondent of the Inquirer, writing February 3d, says American gold is very feverish, irregular, and lower, opening at 55, declining to 53½, advancing to 57, and closing steady at 55½ ©55½.

div3.p:
The Washington correspondent of the Inquirer says Gen. Butler refuses to take command at new Orleans if Banks is allowed to take the troops all away to Texas.
[No change will be made in the War Department.]

A correspondence from Falmouth, of February 1, says the rebels are still strengthening their works along the river, working hard at rifle pits, &c. No attempt is made to interfere with them.--Indeed, it would be unnecessary, for there is no one on this side the river foolish enough to believe that we would select Fredericksburg as the crossing place, were another attempt at crossing to be made.
So our "friends" the rebels will doubtless have their labor for nothing.

Gen. Hooker will thoroughly reorganize before making a forward movement.
He will probably abolish grand divisions, a system introduced by Burnside.
It has not worked well, each division being isolated as a separate army.
Officers did not yield cordial support to Burnside, but openly opposed his plans and policy.
Hooker will make the army a unit. He is a live man and will reward merit and punish skulkers and incompetents.

There are scores of officers who constantly use disaffected language, who say they are tired of the war, want to go home, don't like the proclamation, and would leave the service if they could do it "honorably."
Couch succeeds Sumner, and Howard succeeds Couch, Col. J. T. Owen has been made a Brigadier.
The mall boats from Washington to Aqula Creek are crowded daily with citizens, chiefly from New York and Pennsylvania.

Dates from Vicksburg are to the 30th.
A Cairo telegraph of the 31, says Grant has arrived at Vicksburg, and the canal work is progressing.
A rebel battery commands the lower end of the canal.
"The Richmond Whig, of the 22d ult, says Gen. Longstreet, with thirteen brigades, has gone to Tennessee."

The gunboat New Bra was attacked on Sunday night, at 11 o'clock, near Island No.10, by the guerrillas, with three places of cannon.
The fight lasted till daylight, when the rebels retired.
Fort Donelson was attacked at an early hour Tuesday morning, and the engagement was still going on at 4 P. M.

St. Louis. Feb. 3.--General Loan, commanding Central District of Missouri, has issued orders that all bushwhackers.
guerrillas, Confederate recruiting officers, etc, found shall be promptly executed, and any officer failing to do so shall be court-martialed for disobedience of orders.
Col. Windham, on the 3d had just returned from Warrenten, which he captured Monday night. He found no enemy at the Springs or at Waterloo.
It is rumored in Washington that the rebels are going to propose terms of peace.

A letter says that "the rebels in front of the army of the Potomac seem to think they have made a mistake by weakening their force, believing they might now successfully advance had they not sent troops to Murfreesboro', Vicksburg, &c. So much of our plan, then, is already successful."
A strong squadron has begun the work of the bombardment of Galveston.
The latest from Suffolk is that the rebels were sixteen miles from there Monday night-- "this side of the Blackwater"--but there was no evidence of an immediate engagement.
A leading Havana house sent word to the Columbia when leaving that the Creto had been destroyed.

The Chicago Tribune.
(extreme Abolition) says "Old Whitecoat Horace Grealey never had much political sense, and he is never so dangerous to anybody, as to his friends." [The rogues are falling out].

The Herald says, editorially, that 28 Major and Brigadier-Generals are not in active service.
Opposite Cassius M. Clay's name, is "not in service since June 17, 1862, when appointed.
Assigned to Gen. Butler, but did not report." He should be ignominiously dismissed.
If Stauton wants to send him a discharge, he is advertised lecturing about the country.
Senator Lane proposes a bill to stop the pay of "drones and fancy Generals."

If the Vicksburg "out-off" fails, two battles will have to be fought--one at Vicksburg and one at Port Hudson.
If it succeeds, the capture of the latter will alone be necessary.

Secretary Stauton (says the Herald) should be summarily dismissed and properly punished for the arrest of the Philadelphia editor. "Stauton's blunder is not a bit more absurd and ridiculous than the article eulogizing Jeff. Davis. "
With the excessive taxes on commerce, thinks the Herald, added to the danger of being captured at sea by the Alabama and Oreto, our shipping stands a poor chance in these days of rebellion.

The Herald has a fierce article on the designs of Napoleon, as avowed in his latter to Forey.
It warns him of the fate of the First Napoleon's attempt to overrun Russia, and prophecies, if he persists in Mexico, "like his illustrious relation, he will surely find a St. Helena." "Our Government will now doubtless lay asides all other questions, and will work for the Union.
We shall now hear no more of the negro, unless the people in power are mad. We must save the Union, and than assert our supremacy upon the American continent.
We shall expect no more assurances from the authorities at Washington that 'our relations with foreign Powers are quite satisfactory.' This sham Napoleon has himself exposed.
The American people are well aware that a crisis in their national existence has arrived, and they would prefer, doubtless that their Government should not systematically deceive them upon any subject."
The consideration of resolutions on arbitrary arrests, was made the special order for Monday next in the New York legislature.

Gold 156¼ to 153¼ and closed at 156¾.
Exchange 174 to 175.
Garibaldi accepts, with gratitude and confidence, the Presidency of a new Committee formed in Rome.
The Paris correspondent of the London Telegraph, of January 16th, says:

q.p:
"In the 'Yellow Book' I find a letter written by Baron Mercier, the French Ambassador at Washington, in which that diplomatist informs the Minister of Foreign Affairs that he had endeavored to word his replies in such a manner as to accustom the Government of the White House to the recognition.
of the South by France in case hostilities should continue to rage without any marked result in favor of the North.".

div3.p: The Herald's financial article says the increasing difficulty of carrying said, and uncertainty whether speculation in it will be forbidden by Congress, discourages the bulls.

In the New York Legislature, on Tuesday, the ballot for B. S. Senator stood as follows: Morgan 86, Dix 1, Corning 70, Dickinson 1.
So Ex. Gov. Morgan was elected Senator from that State.
Gen. McClellan made a speech in Boston on the 3d, saying that he was engaged preparing a history of the Peninsular campaign.
The privateers Retribution had burned five U. S. merchant vessels near the island of St. Thomas.

No U. S. Senator has yet been elected in Missouri.
The last ballot stood: Brown 39, Phelpa 41, Glover 29, Breckenridge 30, scattering 6.

The regiments engaged in the recent fight at Blackwater river were the 112th, 130th, and 69th N. Y., 167th and 165th Pa; 5th Brass; 13th Ind.infantry; 14th Pa cavalry, and two batteries of artillery.
The loss of the Federals was 24 killed and 80 wounded.

Horace Greeley, over his own signature, writes a bitter reply to an attack upon him by Thurlow Weed.
Be says he does not believe the war can last three or four years, and that it is to be sattied one way or the other in three or four months.
The New York Herald, of the 3d, has au editorial on "A Revolutionary Idea in our Government." It says:

q.p: Three important measures are before Congress, which we may expect to be passed and approved this session--

div3.p: First--The financial scheme of Secretary Chase, which substantially contemplates the absorption of the local banks of the several States as banks of circulation, into the paper money issues of the Federal Government.
Second--The militia and enlistment bill of Senator Wilson, which provides for conferring upon the President absolute authority over the militia of the several States.
Third--A bill granting to the President, at his discretion, the power of suspending the writ, of habeas corpus.

The President will then be practically an autocrat, with the powers of au absolute despotism. -- We are now in the throes of dissolution and reconstruction, and whether the end will be "the Union as it was." or a pair of military despots, or a half dozen petty mock republics of the South American school, no man can at present determine.
The Southern people are, to a great extent, the willing victims of the most ferocious reign of terror of modern times.
We have a divided North against a united South, while our Government is steadily drifting towards a military consolidation of power — legislative, executive, and judicial.
Nor do we see any inviting door of escape open to us. If these measures pass, we can hardly expect their repeal during the next Congress.

The Herald express the board that "the ever shadow as Government will go on tilled it fall have admit ...solidates despotism or in a number of petty military republics, incessantly fighting each other." It goes out "Our hope is in the land and naval forces now in the field.
If they fall, it will be because of incompetency of the Administration.
We must settle with this rebellion with our fleets and armies now, or the Union and our popular institutions will, we fear by a divided country, and despotic loaticullers on be universal marccy."
The whole tone of the piper if despairing.

div4.head: War with France Derated in the United State Senate.
div4.p:
In the Senate of the United States Mr. McDougall thought it was time the designs of France should receive the attention of the Government.--He thought France was already making war. He charged Napoleon with designing to conquer Mexico, seizing California, and take command of the Mississippi river.
He offered resolutions, which were taken up by aves 22, nays 16 --extreme Abolitionists voting in the negative, on the ground that the discussion of war with France would delight the rebels, as said in the debate by Sumner.
McDougall, in his speech, stated that the United State ought to send at once 10,000 men to assist the Mexicans in driving the French into the sea. His voice was emphatically for war, to maintain the fundamental principles of the Monroe doctrine, involving the national honor.
In the House of Representatives the Bankrupt bill was laid on the table by yeas 60, nays 53.

div3.head: [General Newspaper Dispatch.]
div3.p:
--Northern dates, of the 4th inst, have been received here.
The following is a summary of the news:

div4.head: Important from France.
div4.p: The Paris correspondence of the London Telegraph says that the following is an analysis of what occurs in the "Yellow Book," which is usually distributed to the chambers, but has been withheld this year, concerning America, viz:

q.p: Mercier informs the Minister of Foreign Affairs that in his correspondence with the U. S. Government he had endeavored to word his replies in such manner as to accustom that Government to the recognition of the south by France, in case hostilities should continue without any marged result in favor of the North.

div4.p:
At the same time Mercier wrote to Reward on the subject of loss to French subjects by reason of the impossibility of corresponding with the population of the Southern States.
These leases are represented to be $8,000,000 in New Orleans alone.

Mercier demanded that French Coranis in the Confederats States should be permitted to forward business correspondence.
Seward referred the matter to Line on Stating that the demand was of the highest moment.

On 27th February, 1862, Thouvenal asked Mercier to deny, as he had previously done, the recognition of the Confederate Government by France, she intending to remain strictly neutral; but, on the 6th of March the Minister of Foreign Affairs wrote Mercier, stating that success by the Federal army in Tennessee might soon end the campaign, without the honor of the Government at Washington suffering, and that France greatly desired to see that Government endeavoring to solve the difficulty peaceably.
Thouvenal added, that the Cabinet at Washington alone could lay down the basis of compromise, necessity for which is felt more keenly every day.

This was the beginning of the efforts which terminated in the note of Drouyn De L Huys to England and Russia.
When Mercier communicated this note to Seward, he replied that any step on the part of neutral Powers would only result in complicating the difficulties, Mercier, in his letter in forming Thouvenal of this conversation, added, that "nobody pretended to reconnect the South to the Union against its will, but only to give it a lesson, and to withdraw it from the influence of its present leaders, so that it might return of its own accord.
The Federals are determind to carry out the trial to the end, and if after that the majority of the Southern population persist in wishing to separate from the Union--well, it will be suffered to do so"

A dispatch, bearing date April 13th, says that Mercier's visit to Richmond was undertaken at the suggestion of Seward, who then believed in the speedy re- establishment of the Union.
Mercier came to an understanding with Seward that his journey should not be connected with recognition of the South, but only an attempt to bring about an arrangement.
Seward charged Mercier to state at Richmond that the North was not actuated by sentiments of revenge, and that great satisfaction would be afforded the North by the sight of Southern Senators in Washington.
Mercier mentions that the most important conversation he had was with Mr. Benjamin.
That gentleman said that the South had committed a four pas by relying too much on foreign interference; but the illusion had been dispelled.
The Southern people were unanimous in their determination to separate, and would fight to the bitter end.
After relating this conversation in extense Mercier adds in his dispatch that everybody held the same language, and nobody hesitated to declare that the re-establishment of the Union was impossible.

An editorial article in the Philadelphia Inquirer, of the 4th inst, says that "drunken Magruder's feat at Galveston was hardly a politic movement, for it has raised the cry of 'Dalenda est Galveston,' and a strong squadron has done the work of bombardment."

In another article on Napoleon's letter to Forney, the same paper states that "thus the- sensitive point of American policy is not only rudely shocked, but the charished tradition of a continent sanctioned by successive generations has been defiantly set at naught." And further states that "if the arms of the United States were not shackled by the gigantic rebellion now waging against her authority, could such declarations be made without filling a demand for war from Maine to the frontiers of Texas?"

New Orleans Feb. 3.--Gen. Banks has left the city with his staff.
He started up the Mississippi for the purposes connected with the expedition against Vicksburg and Port Hudson.
A general movement of troops and transports has also been made.
The entice Banks expedition is unquestionably at the present time afloat.
Nearly all the war vessels stationed at New Orleans have accompanied the expedition.

The Philadelphia Inquirer, of the 4th, has a leader commencing-- "Every eye attempts to pierce the clouds which shut out the distant fields of war. Every friend meets his fellow with questions as to the condition of things, and expectancy mingled with hopes and fears is again the order of the day." After confessing inability to find anything hopeful in the Federal condition, the article states that there are rumors that the rebels are going to propose terms of peace!

div3.head: From Tennessee.
div3.p:
--A dispatch to the Augusta press from McMinasside.
Tenn, dated 5th instant, a vs: Information from Kentucky states that an Ohio and Kentucky (Federal) regiment had fought each other — for an hour and a half, resulting as fellows: 8 Ohio s killed, 17 wounded; 5 Kentuckian killed, 11 wounded.

Gen. Reynolds's (Yankee) division moved to Alexandria, Tenn., yesterday, for the purpose of destroying mills.
A portion of Morgan's cavalry fought them several hours, but owing to the enemy's force had to fall back.
The enemy's loss was 11 killed, 37 wounded, and 28 prisoners. Our loss was one wounded.

div3.head: The Press Convention.
div3.p:
--The Press Convention adjourned to-day.
The proceedings will be published to-morrow.
A "Press Association of the Confederate States" has been organized, with Dr. R. W. Gibbes, of Columbia, S. C., is President of the Board of Directors.
Augusta, Feb. 6--The Convention proceedings have not yet been made public.

The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at 10 o'clock A M to-day, from the residence of her father, on Brook Avenue.

Her funeral will take place to-morrow (Sunday) afternoon, at 2½ o'clock, from St. Peter's Cathedral.
The friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend.
on the 5th inst., at his residences, on Union Hill, after a painful illness of 14 days, William H Brummall, in the 27th year of his age.

he leaves a wife and one child and many friends to mourn their irreparable loss.
As a husband and father he was kind and affectionate; as a brother he was loving and dutiful; as a friend be was generous and true.
Beloved by all who knew him, he has passed away in the spring-time of his life.
His sufferings were severe, but he bore them with patience, and now he has gone to that rest from which no traveller returns.
May he rest in peace.
It is hard to give him up, but yet it must be so.

lg.l: when in this world of grief and pain
we from our friends must saver,
Tis sweet to look beyond this scene,
where we shall meet forever.
Sweet thought this earth is not our rest,
Where troubles crowd together;
But with our Jesus we shall dwell,
And reign with Him forever.

div4.p: on the 23d day of December, 1862, at the residence of Mr. Thos Gentry, in the county of Hanover, Edward F Hay, in the 40th year of his age, after an illness of 10 days.
he leaves a devoted mother, and many relatives and friends to mourn their irreparable loss.

lg.l: Dearest brother, thou hast left us,
we thy loss most deeply feel;
but his Goa who hath bereft us,
he can all our sorrows heal.
Yet again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life has fled;
Then in Heaven with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell tear is-shod.

div3.head: Important to conscripts, stragglers, and deserters.
div3.p:
--In accordances with order No. 39, issued by Major General Geo W Smith, we hereupon assume the duties of Recruiting Officers for the county of Henrico, city of Richmond, and vicinity.
To all concerned notices is hereby given that the operation of the Conscript law is partially suspended in this department.
Any person willing to volunteer will be allowed to select his own company, provided it be in this Department, and will be entitled to the bounty and all other benefits which are provided for by law to volunteers.
In like manner all conscripts who come forward voluntarily and make application to this office will be enrolled into any company they may select in this command.
It is hoped and believed that the liberal inducements herein tendered to conscripts will meet with a prompt response, and thus aid to securing ample means for the common defence.

By like command we are instructed to arrest all stragglers and deserters from the army.
To those who report voluntarily we are authorized to declare a free and fall pardon, with the exception of forfeiture of pay for the time absent.
Those who fall to report will be arrested and confined until they can be forwarded to their companies under guard.
The co-operation of the people in discountenancing straggling and inducing the laggard to return to duty is hereby earnestly invoked.
We can be found at any time between the hours of 10 A M and 3 P M, in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main sts.

closer.signed: Lt and Rect'g Officer for Henrico co;
Lt and Rect'g 6 fillter for Richmond city and vicinity;
Rect'g Officer for Richmond city and vicinity.

div3.p:

Gen G W Smith, all Absentees from Capt H. B. Dickinson's company D, 59th Vareg, are hereby notified to report to camp by 10th February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except forfeiture of pay" for the time of absence.
Should they not report by the time specified, they will be tried as deserters by the new Court Martial now, in session, and if found guilty punished as such when ever apprehended.

Chief Point in the Laws of War and Neutrality.
Search and Blockade — With the changes of 1856 and those now proposed.
By John Fraser Macqueen, Esq. one of Her Majesty's counsel.
Price. $1; by mail, $1.25.

* * * This admirable little work is from the pen of an able and learned British jurist already well known by his many works of the highest authority among the legal profession.
The present production is of great interest and research, and should be in the hands of every stateman and scholar.
[From the Richmond Dispatch.]
"This book is the most important work on international law which has been issued in the Confederacy, especially bearing, as it does on questions which are now uppermost in this country."
[From the Richmond Whig]

"This is a reprint of an English work, the appearance of which in this country, at the present period, is most opportune.
It should be in the hands of every member of Congress and of every other man whose station renders it essential that he should be familiar with the important subjects on which it treats,"
Address orders to

div3.head: Seventy-five Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Is offered for the apprehension and delivery of my slave William Henry, who disappeared from the fortifications around Richmond about the 10th of December.
Said slave is about 19 years of age, 5 feet high, thick set, thick of speech, gruff in manner of speaking, and generally clears his throat before beginning; has a peculiarly formed head, protuberance on the back of it, and eyes somewhat popped.
The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery of said slave to me in Danville, or lodged in the jail in Richmond so that I get him in possession.

Virginia clothing.
The owner of said boy is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges and take him away, or he will be dealt with as the law directs.

div3.head: Deserters from Hooker's army.
div3.p:
On Sunday last a squad of thirteen deserters from Hooker's army reached Harrisonburg, Va., from near Fredericksburg, and on Wednesday another squad of fifteen arrived there.
They hailed from New York, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin regiments.
They represent the officers in that army to be as much demoralized as the men, and crowds of the latter are leaving every day. Many are waiting to get their pay and then desert.
Some said Lincoln's proclamation was the cause of their quitting, but the majority frankly said that "whipping the South was played out, " and they didn't intend to "fool 'round" it any more.

div3.head: Financial and commercial.
div3.p:
Specie and Bank Notes.--The premium for Gold, selling rate, continues at $2.25; Silver $2.10. The supply of bank currency is diminishing, and rates are stiffening; but brokers are still generally asking 35 cents for Virginia and North Carolina, and 40 for Georgia and South Carolina notes.
We quote Exchange on London at $2.25.

Bonds and Stocks.--Sales of Confederate bonds (8 per cents.) continue to be made at $100½ and interest, payable in the new currency, which is only fundable in 7 per cent. bonds.
All other bonds and stocks remain at last quotations except Farmers' Bank, which is 50 cts higher.
We quote Va. sixes, registered, at $108, dull; North Carolina sixes, (saleable in the North,) $186½ do. do.
eights, $116 and interest; Farmers' Bank stock, $107½ Bank of the Commonwealth do., $167½ Exchange Bank, $108; Traders' Bank, $105.

Groceries, Produce, Etc.--Sugar is lower.--We quote at 83 @88c by the bbl. Molasses, $9@9.50.
Coffee, $3.50@4.. Butter, $1.50 @1.60--Bacon, 95c@$1.10 for hog round.
