div3.head: Administrator's Sale of Eighty-six acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep-Nun Turnpike, at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Saturday, the 14th day of February, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and Jas. Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms, Barn, Stable, and other necessary out houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson.
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.

P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r, fe 3.

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of Fine Wood, 100,000 feet of Seasoned Lumber, and one Steam Saw Mill.
Will be sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 12th day of February next, at the Saw Mill lately occupied by Rowland & Shriver, dec'd, about three miles from Cabind Point, Surry co., Va., the following property to wit:

1. Horse and Harness, 2 yoke of Oxen, 1 Steam Saw Mill and Fixtures, Wagons, Carts, Carryings; also, about 100,000 feet of seasoned Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Pine Wood, 5 Bogie's cross out Saws, 1 pair large Patent Balances, 40 halds of Nay, and all the Fixtures, too numerous to mention, necessary to carry on a well-kept Saw Mill.
Persons wishing to purchase the wood or lumber, can have every facility for shipping to Richmond or Petersburg by the Norfolk, and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when terms will be made known.

lg.l: Calm as that second summer which precedes
The first fall of the snow,
In the second sunlight of berals deeds,
The city bides the foe.
As yet, behind their ramparts stern and proud.
Her bolted thunders sleep,--
Dark Sumter, like a bafflement cloud,
Looks o'er the solemn deep.
No Calpe frowns from lofty cliff or scar.
To guard the holy strand;
But Mou hells in leash her dogs of war
Above the level sand.
And down the d thousand guns cinched,
Unseen, beside, the flond--
Like tigers in some Orient jungle or cinched
That wait and watch for blued.
Meanwhile, through is still with trade,
Walk grave and thoughtful men.
Whose hands may one day wield the patriot's blade
As lightly as the pen.
And maiders with such eyes as would grow dim
Over a bleeding bound.
Seem each one to have caught the strength of him
Whose sword the ly bound.
Thus girl without and garrisoned at home,
U patient following day,
Old Charleston looks from root and spire and dome
Across her tranquil bay.
Ships, through a hundred foes, from Saxon lands
And spicy Indian ports,
Bring Saxon steel and iron to her hands,
And summer to her courts.
But still, along you dim Atlantic line,
The only headle smoke
Creeps like a harmless mist above the brine,
From some frail, floating oak.
Shall the spring dawn, and she, still clad in smiles,
And with an unscathed brow,
East in the strong arms of her palm-crowned
As fair and free as now!
We know not; in the temple of the Fates,
God has inscribed her doom;
And, all untroubled in her faith, she waits
The triumph or the tomb.

div3.p:
Commission and Forwarding House.
We have connected with this business a large Auction Room.
We have a very large and commodious fire-proof building.
Anything consigned to us, going North or South of this place, shall meet our prompt attention.
References.--Jesse H. Lindsay, Cathier of the Bank of Cape Fear; John A Gilmore, Attorney at Law; Hon James R. McLane, Attorney at Law.

closer.signed: J. & F. Garrett, West Market st.,

div3.head: New Commission House.
div3.p: --On the 1st of February next, we shall open, under the style of Spencee & Co, a Commission House for the sale of all Kinds Country Produce, in the office formerly occupied by J. Fannill, in Shockoe Ware house building.
By strict attention to the interest of our friends, prompt returns, we hope to share their patronage.
div3.closer:
A. R. Venable,
Of Prince Edward county, Va.
Thos. J. Spencer,
Of Charlotte C. H. Va. ja 16--eod7t*

div3.head: Commercial school.
div3.p:
--C. M. Ligg at Teacher of Book-Keeping, Penmanship, and Card Marking, is prepared to give instruction in the above branches six evenings per week, at Prof Cone's commercial school room, on Franklin street, between 8th and 9th, near the Capitol.
Leesons will be given to such as desire it at their residences during the day. Visiting Cards neatly written to order.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent one or two rooms, for the accommodation of three women and four children, widowns and orphans of Confederate soldiers.
Any person having such rooms to rent will perform of charity and receive a fair compensation, by applying at the Do not Army Com Y. M. C. A., corner of 10th and Bank sts.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A lady, thoroughly qualified to teach the higher English branches, Latin, French Nurse Drawing, and Oil Painting on canvas to instruct one pupil in a private family, near Richmond.
For one who can come well recommended a liberal salary will be given.
Apply to "H, " Box 924, Richmond city Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman who has a few hours of the day and night to apar destructs of obtaining a situation as Accountant, Copyist, or would keep a set of books, or clerk in any form.
Address "Francis," through Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.--Marines.
div3.p:
--$500 bounty, and pay from $15 to $25 per month.
By law persons subject to enrollment and conscripts, at anything before being mastered into a company or vestment may enlist in the marine corps for the war or for three years, at their option.
Good clothing and subsistence furnished by Government.
Apply at the office on 9th, between Main and Cary sts.

div3.head: Wanted — to Auction and Commission houses.
div3.p:
--A gentleman of many years' experiences in the commission business, and in making up sales and accounts current wishes a Situation in an Auction or Commission House.
A fair salary will be required.
Address "H M B," Post Office

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --At W. R. Polks, No. 75 Main street:

div3.head: Office E. F. & P. Railroad Co.,February 2d, 1863.
div3.p:
Wanted.--A competent Clerk and Agent for this company at Hanover Junction. One not liable to conscription preferred.
None need apply without the most reliable testimonials of character and qualifications.

div3.head: Wanted — Board
div3.p:
--By the wife of a soldier now in service, by the week or month, 1st of May, in some private family within six miles of Richmond.
Advance payment will be made, if required.
Address. "L. A. H," stating terms and locality.

div3.head: Wanted

div3.closer:
C. H. Dennis,
Opposite Metropolitan Hall,
Franklin st. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Wanted — a Ditcher.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a first-rate Ditcher, to work upon a place eight miles from Richmond.
Apply immediately to
div3.closer:
O. H. Dennish, Franklin st.,
Opposite Metropolitan Hall. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Situation in some Mercantile House or Hotel, as Clerk by a youth 15 years of age, who has had some experience.--References given.
Address "C," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:

A very liberal salary is offered.
None but a really first-class teacher and performer need apply.
Apply to Prof. DecŒNiel, from 2 to 4 o'clock P M, corner of 1st and Grace streets, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted to rent
div3.p:
--A suitable Room to carry on the Carrying and Finishing Business in or I will take a room and Carry and Finish for any one engaged in cutting and working Leather — either Calf, Harness, or Russett.
Apply at No. 75 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman connected with one of the Departments, who has a few hours leisure in the evening, is desirous of getting some employment in writing up sets of Books or Copying.
Has been keeping books for the last ten years. Address Box 1,058, Richmond Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted--
div3.p:
--20d. Teamsters, for which annum will be paid and rations and clothing furnished, or $25 per month and ration.
These Teamsters are needed for the Forage Department, and not soliable to transfer at some other brancher of the Government service.
Apply at Hanover Court-House, or No. 67 Main street, up stair.

div3.head: Wanted.

To one who can come well recommended a good price will be given.
Apply to
div3.closer:

Address "R. V. Gaxx." Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:

Reference given. --Also, a situation for a qualified Carpenter.
Address same.

div3.head: Wanted.

Direct to "Amicus," through Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.

--A good front Room, on 1st or 2d floor, situated in the business part of the city.
For such an one a liberal rent will be paid, by addressing "J. H. R." Box 355, Richmond P. O, care of J. A. His.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:

None other need apply.

div3.head: Wanted.

div3.head: Wanted.

div3.p: --wanter to the C. S. Armory, foot of 5th street and Canal, two or three good

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, since July, 1862, a negro man named Willis, belonging jointly to A E Milber, dec'd, late of Nottoway county, Va. The said negro is a bright mulatto, about 50 years of age, 5 feet 4 inches high, slightly bald, steps quick, and sloops a little when walking.
He was purchased of Mr. John Pride, of Amella county, where he has a wife.
He is a good boot and shoemaker, and may be passing as a free man. I will give the above reward if confined in any jail, where we can get him. Address H T Miller, or Dr. J A Ageew, at centers of A R Miller's estate, Richmond.

div3.head: Two hundred and fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For my woman Vina, who escaped from the Bollingbrook Hotel, in Petersburg, the 12th January.
She had on a homespun dress.
She is about 23 years old, dark skin.
She was hired to Mr. John Earman, in Petersburg, in 1862.
I bought her from Mr. Alpheun A Rawlett, in Chesterfield.
She may be harbored by some person in or next Petersburg.
If so, I will give fifty dollars in addition to the above reward for their detection.
If caught she may be placed in jail in Petersburg or Richmond.
Address any information concerning her to H A Pearch Richmond, Va., or Mr. F. Jackson, at the office of the South Side Railroad, Petersburg, Va.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on Monday last, a Negro Woman named Kitty, aged 40 years. Kitty is black, of medium height, rather stout, has lost a portion of her front teeth, and her eye teeth protects so as to be quite notionable.
Kitty was originally from the neighborhood of Louisa Court-House, and may be attempting to make her way back.
She took will her several Linsey dresses and other articles of wearing apparel.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and confinement in jail so that I get her again.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my residence on the night of the 25th January, my house boy George.
The said boy is a bright mulatto, 5 feet 8 inches high.
He had on when he left a gray coat, gray pants, shoes that had been smartly worn, and gray cap. He is 22 years old, with fine set of teeth and full sets of black hair.--He has a little impediment in his speech when spoken to. He may be making his way to our army.
If caught in the county, I will pay $25; if ought out of the county and lodged in jail so that I get him again, I will pay $30.

closer.signed: Verdon P O, Hanover county, Va.

div3.head: Attempt at murder--$200 reward.
div3.p:
--The undersigned offer a reward of two hundred Dollars for the apprehension and confinement in any of the jails of this city or of King' William county, of a negro named Richard, who on Friday night last, January 30th, made a brutal, and, it is feared, successful, attempt to murder the manager upon their plantation in King William county.
Richard is a small and delicately-formed negro, about 18 or 19 years of age, and is marked on the side of his head by a , upon which there is no hair.
He was hired last year to Mr. John D. Quarter, of this city, but ran away, and upon his return stated that he accompanied the Thomas Artillery, of this city, for six months as a servant.--He is no doubt at this time making his way to the lines of our army, near Fredericksburg, or is lurking in or near this city.
div3.closer:
P N Aylett,
Wraylett,
Richmond, Feb. 2, 1863. fe 2--2t*

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber on the 1st day of February, a dark brown skin negro man, 6 feet high, named Peter, about 23 years old. I will give the above reward to any person who will bring him to me, or have him confined in any, jail in the State that I may set him. He has a wife in Powhatan county, and was recently bought in Goochland county.
Va.
div3.closer:
Daniel F. Ward,
Fairs Plantation, Chesterfield county, Va. fe 3--2w

div3.head: Notice--$100 reward
div3.p:
--I will give the above reward for the apprehension of my negro boy James, though sometimes called Old Clarks.
He is very dark complicated, low of stature and very quick spoken, and very polite when spoken to. He left the promises of Mr G A W Taylor on or about the 15th of February, 1862.
He has been seen in the city of Richmond during the last summer, and it is very likely he is at this time in the employ of some of the officers of the Confederate Army.

closer.signed: Agent for J E W Watkins.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--$6 reward offered for a negro man named Tom. He has a blemish about the left eye; is a big stout negro, and about six feet high.
The above reward will be given for his delivery to M. E D Racho, on 14th street, near Exchange alley.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, a negro woman named Jark.
She is tall and stout, dark complexion, a flat, receding forehead; large eyes and month, the forefinger of the right hand is off to the first joint, occasioned by a whithow; and is about 16 years of age, but from size and appearance one would suppose, she was 20.
She has been seen in Richmond.
Her mother, named Charlotte is hired out by E D Each, General Agent.
I will give the above reward to any one, black or white, who will deliver her to me at my residence, in Henrico county confine her in jail, or inform me where she is, so that I can get her.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the camp of the 15th Louisiana regiment, near Guinea's Station my boy Nelson.
He is about 5 feet 5 or 6 inches high, dark griffe, rather quick spoken, about 30 years of age. He left camp about three weeks since, and is supposed to be in some of the adjoining camps, or on his way to Richmond.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to me, or for any information that may lead to his recovery.
div3.closer:
Wm C Miorie,
Capt Co G, 15th La Reg't,
Near Guinea Station fe 2--6t*

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th inst., a black Girl, about 14 years old, not very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mars W Coleman, of Caroline county, and may be making her way back.
I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to Bill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, about two weeks ago, a negro boy named Henry.
Said boy is about sixteen years old, five feet high, round face, and good teeth, no doubt will say he is free; has been seen in Richmond in the last few days.
He may have gone to the army.
I will pay the above reward of fifty dollars for his delivery in any jail in the State.

div3.head:
Camp near Port Royal,
January, 30, 1863.
div3.p: Arrest the Deserter.--The usual reward of $30 will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or to the officer in command of Castle Thunder Richmond city, of the following deserters from Company "A." 8th Regiment Louisiana Volunteers:

list.item:
1. Private Jas Loyd, a native of Ireland, about 22 years of age, red hair and beard, ruddy complexion, marked by the small pox somewhat over 6 feet in height, and a teamster by occupation.
He is supposed to have joined a Virginia cavalry company.
2. Private Jno H Cummins, a native of New York State, 21 years old, light hair, no beard, fair complexion, blue eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and a painter by trade.
3. Private Patrick Donohoe, a native of Ireland, about 37 years old, light black hair, mid-complexion on, quick of speech and motion, about 5 feet 5½ inches high and a gardener by trade.
4. Private Patrick Fitzgerald, a native of Ireland, near 40 years of age, black hair and beard slightly bald, black eyes, about 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, and a city laborer.

5. Private Wm Reagan a native of New York State 30 years old, auburn hair, hazel eyes, stout built, some 5 feet 7 inches high, and a blacksmith by trade.
He deserted in the early part of last June, and is supposed to be in Richmond city, as I lately received a notice from Capt West, one of the Quartermasters of that city, that he had paid him $174.58 as pay, bounty, and clothing money.
I will add $20 for Reagan's arrest, thus making the reward in his case $50.

closer.signed: Capt. co A, 8th Reg La Vols.

div3.head: Camp Battery no. 2, Jan. 31, 1863.
div3.p:
Last Chance for Absentees.--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General Smith, all members of Capt T P Wilkinson's Company, (C,) 10th Battalion Va Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to camp by the 10th of February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except the forfeiture of pays for the time absent.
Should they not report by the time specified they will be considered Deserters and tried by the new Court Marshall now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
John W Turner,
2d Lt Commanding Co
10th Bet Va Heavy Artillery fe 2--3t*

div3.head:
Camp Battery no. 1,
January 31, 1863.
div3.p: Last Chance for Absentees.--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A, 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers, Heavy Artillery, now absent are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent — Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the now Military Court now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
J W Barlow,
Capt Commd'g Co A, 10th Batt Va Vols.
Heavy Artillery fe 2--2t*

div3.p:
By special No. 35, issued by command of Major-Gen G W Smith, I am detailed on Recruiting Serton, for the city of Richmond and Hanover Louisa Albemarle Orlean and Culpeper counties.
The "letter of instructions" accompanying the order directs the announcement of the partial suspension of the operation of the Conscript law, so as to allow conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection, without passing through camps of instruction, and receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers; " and authorizes me, "upon application, to muster conscripts into any company they may select." These instructions are read upon the following language, contained in the structure letter from Adjutant and Inspector General Cooper, to Major-Gen G W Smith, commanding Army of North Carolina.
Such persons or reliable to conscription will be allowed to join any particular company and regiment requiring recruit within the command in which the officers may be serving.
In his manner, such persons as are within conscript ages (between 18 and 40) and who first come forward and offer themselves for service will be allowed to volunteer and will receive all the benefits which are secured by law to volunteers."

In pursuance of these orders and instructions, I have established my headquarters at Gorgenville Orange county, Va., where all persons interested who reside in Louisa, Orange, Albemarle, and Culpeper counties, will report, while those in Hanover, and Richmond city, and vicinity, either address me by letter as before indicated, or call on Mr. C F Weig.
Gen. No. 24 Pearl street, Richmond.
An opportunity is hereby efforded all persons within the limits before recited who are liable to service to discharge themselves of-that obligation without incurring the odinan which is supposed to attach to the farm conscript.
I will recruits upon the terms already state for the company to which I am attached, or for any company is the command of Maj Gen Smith.

The Major-General Commanding, as well as the Adjutant and Inspector General, earnestly desires that the able-bodied men of the State shall promptly act upon this suggestion, and with a willing and come forward and fill up the ranks of the companies in the services without waiting to be constrained to duty.

div3.head: Headq'rs camp of instruction, Richmond, Jan. 31 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward each will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the following Deserters from this camp:
James Morgan, a substitute, 47 years old, gray eyes, light hair, florid complexion, five feet eight inches high, born in Virginia, and by occupation a seamen.
F Callahan, a substitute 45 years old, blue eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 5½ inches high, born in Mississippi, and by occupation a sailor.
J W Gribben, a substitute, 46 years old, gray eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 5 ½ inches high, born in Ireland, and by occupation a laborer.
James Dunn, a substitute 47 years old blue eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high, born in Virginia, and by occupation a laborer.
John Saunders, a substitute 45 years old blue eyes, dark hair, florid complexion 5 feet 5 ½ inches high, born in Scotland, and by occupation laborer.
div3.closer:
By order of Maj T G Peyton.
Jas E Heath, La and Adja. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at Castle Thunder, or where I can of Private Patrick Deegay, who deserted from my company January 31st.
The said Drewry is an Irishman by birth represents himself forty six years of age, though apparently not more than thirty, has blue eyes, light hair, five feet six inches high, and has had the small pox. Drewry was a substitute for James M. Comes, of Hitles County Virginia.

closer.signed: Capt. Co. A, 2d Va. Regt., Wise's Brigade.

div3.head:
Office City Gas Works,
January 28th 1863.
div3.p:
Four hundred Dollars reward — Ranaway, from the City Gas Works, four negro men. Fo Hughes is about 5 feet high, dark skin and about 25 years old, R'Ch'd Emeson, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, mulatto, and about 23 years old, Frank 5 feet 8 inches high, dark skin, and about 25 years old. Frank was formerly on the York River railroad.
Elijah Campbell, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark skin, and about 23 years old. The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the four, or $100 for the delivery of at the City Gas Works, Rocketts.

the undersigned members of my Company are deserters.
I will pay the usual to have them arrested:

div3.head:
Headq'rs President's guard,
February 24, 1863.
div3.p:
all members of this company now must report within 48 hours, or they will be advertised as deserters.
Sick members must send a Surgeon's certificate.
All those who have with me will report at once to Lieut P P Johnson's Recruiting Office, on Main street, opposite the Post Office, or he considered as deserters.
